Signature; Inscriptions; Watermark, Labels

See Signed

Inscribed in graphite (possibly in artist\'s hand), verso: [Grosz 1934/Bayside L. Isl.]

Old exhibition labels removed from back of frame (now in MIA object file).
medium: Watercolor and brush and black ink over graphite on paper
provenance: John and Myrtle Coe, Bloomington, Minn., (by 1957-98; gave to MIA)
signed: Signed in brown-black ink, LRC: [George Grosz]
text: The German artist George Grosz was known for his satirical antiwar and anticapitalist works, especially his searing condemnations of corrupt and decadent Berlin society. Fervently anti-Nazi, Grosz saw the rising specter of fascism and immigrated to America with his family in 1933 just months before Hitler rose to power. Street Fight in Vienna, painted after Grosz moved to New York, was inspired by a short-lived uprising in Austria in 1934 in which several hundred people died in street battles in Vienna and other cities. Grosz’s fractured composition is reminiscent of photomontage, an assemblage technique he developed in the late 1910s with fellow Dada artist John Heartfield.
title: Street Fight in Vienna
